columns.text: In this problem, we will solve for the equivalent annual cost of a given project.

For the initial cash flow, we will simply add the initial investment as well as the net working capital.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Initial cash flow}&=\$315,000+\$25,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$340,000
\end{aligned}$$

Since these are expenses, then we will take the negative value. Therefore, the initial cash flow is $-\$340,000$

For the present value cash flow, we will simply take the current cash flow and multiply it by the annuity factor. Using an annuity factor table, the corresponding factor is $3.6959$

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Present value cash flow}&=-\$35,000 \times3.6959\\[15 pt]
&=-\$129,356.50
\end{aligned}$$

The present value cash flow is $-\$129,356.50$

Substituting the known values, we can now solve for the net present value:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{NPV}&=-\$340,000-\$129,356.50+\dfrac{\$25,000}{(1+0.11)^5}\\[15 pt]
&=-\$454,520.22
\end{aligned}$$

The net present value of this project is $-\$454,520.22$

Now, we can solve for the equivalent annual cost (EAC).

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{EAC}&=\dfrac{-\$454,520.22}{3.6959}\\[15 pt]
&=-\$122,979.58
\end{aligned}$$

The equivalent annual cost of this project is $-\$122,979.58$
